wiki_catalogs.name: Introduction
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the introduction section focused on the H5 Builder Framework. Explain its purpose as a frontend component library for e-commerce H5 page construction using schema-driven architecture. Document the core architectural principles including Model-View separation, dependency injection, and reactive state management. Highlight key features such as automated resource management, complete lifecycle control, and performance optimizations like lazy loading and virtual scrolling. Provide context on the technology stack including React 19, Vue 3 reactivity system via mobx-vue-lite, and Vite. Include practical examples from the README showing the basic workflow from schema definition to rendering. Address the target audience of frontend developers building dynamic e-commerce experiences and explain how the framework solves common challenges in dynamic page rendering and state management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architectural Layers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the four-layer architecture of the H5 Builder Framework. Describe the Kernel Layer (DI, Model, Disposable) responsible for core abstractions and lifecycle management, the Infrastructure Layer (Bridge, HTTP, Tracker) providing cross-cutting services, the Flow Layer (JobScheduler, ComponentLoader) orchestrating initialization and rendering flow, and the Components/View Layer implementing business logic and UI. Explain the separation of concerns, dependency direction, and encapsulation boundaries between layers. Document how each layer contributes to performance, maintainability, and testability. Include examples from the codebase showing inter-layer interactions, such as how the Flow Layer uses Kernel Layer's DI system to instantiate components that depend on Infrastructure Layer services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Injector Core
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Injector class, which serves as the central container for dependency resolution and service instantiation. Explain its role in managing service lifecycles, resolving dependencies via constructor injection, and supporting both eager and lazy instantiation. Document key methods such as createChild, invokeFunction, createInstance, and dispose, with examples showing how they are used in component initialization and service retrieval. Include implementation details on how the injector maintains a service collection, handles parent-child injector hierarchies, and ensures proper disposal of owned services. Address integration with decorators like @Inject and how dependency metadata is stored using getServiceDependencies. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as missing service errors, circular dependencies, and incorrect service ownership.

wiki_catalogs.name: Model-View Separation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Model-View Separation focused on the strict separation between business logic (Model) and UI rendering (View). Explain how BaseComponentModel and BaseContainerModel encapsulate state, lifecycle, and business logic without any JSX, while Views are pure React components wrapped with observer from mobx-vue-lite for reactivity. Include examples from the README and component_development_guide showing how View components receive the Model as a prop and trigger Model methods. Document the communication flow: View → Model method call → state change → automatic View re-render. Address common issues like non-responsive state updates due to improper property declaration and provide solutions. Highlight best practices such as avoiding business logic in Views and ensuring all reactive properties are declared directly on the Model class. Include performance considerations around observer optimization and unnecessary re-renders.

wiki_catalogs.name: BaseComponentModel
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BaseComponentModel class. Explain its role as the foundation for all component models in the framework, including its generic type parameter for props. Document the constructor's use of mobx-vue-lite's observable to make the entire instance reactive. Detail the lifecycle control properties (isInited, isActive) and data state properties (data, loading, error). Thoroughly explain the lifecycle methods: init (with onInit hook), activate (with onActive hook), deactivate (with onInactive hook), and dispose (with onDestroy hook), including their execution conditions and idempotent behavior. Describe the register method's dual functionality for managing both IDisposable objects and cleanup functions through the DisposableStore. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how to register timers, event listeners, and subscriptions for automatic cleanup. Address performance considerations such as avoiding memory leaks through proper resource registration and the importance of async onInit for initialization logic.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Registration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Component Registration focused on the ComponentRegistry and ComponentService. Explain how components are registered synchronously via register() and registerAll() methods, and how the registry maintains a type-to-ModelClass mapping. Document the internal registry Map structure and its role in schema resolution. Include examples from the codebase showing registration of product-card, tabs-container, and other components. Address common issues such as duplicate registration warnings and unknown component type errors. Provide best practices for organizing component registration in applications.

wiki_catalogs.name: HttpService
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the HttpService infrastructure component. Thoroughly explain its implementation using Axios with request/response interceptors, timeout handling, and retry logic. Document public methods such as get, post, and the interceptor registration pattern. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how HttpService integrates with BridgeService for hybrid app native calls. Explain configuration options for base URLs, headers, and error handling strategies. Address common issues like network failures, CORS policies, and authentication token management. Provide performance optimization tips including caching strategies and request batching. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Lazy Loading
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Lazy Loading focused on the framework's lazy loading capabilities using the DI system's lazy module loading and idle-time processing. Explain how the lazy-service.ts and idle-load.ts modules enable deferred loading of services and components until they are needed. Document the integration with the scheduler system to load non-critical resources during idle periods using requestIdleCallback. Include examples from the codebase showing how LazyService and IdleValue classes work together to optimize initial load time. Provide best practices for identifying which components should be lazily loaded and how to configure lazy loading thresholds.

wiki_catalogs.name: Kernel Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Kernel Layer of the H5 Builder Framework. This layer includes core infrastructure components: Injector for dependency injection, DisposableStore for resource management, BaseComponentModel as the foundation for all component models, and BaseContainerModel for container components. Document each class's methods, properties, parameters, return types, and exceptions with code examples from the actual implementation. Explain the architectural role of each component in the overall system, their relationships, and usage patterns. Include details on lifecycle management, dependency resolution mechanics, and memory leak prevention strategies. Address common implementation pitfalls and performance considerations for each API.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started Questions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content addressing common getting started questions from the FAQ. Cover topics such as suitable use cases for H5 Builder (e-commerce H5 pages, schema-driven dynamic pages, UI-logic separation, high-performance long lists, and complex applications with full lifecycle management). Explain the rationale behind using MobX combined with Vue Reactivity (MobX for simple reactivity APIs, Vue Reactivity for lightweight performance, and mobx-vue-lite for React integration), highlighting the benefits of smaller bundle size compared to MobX-React. Address TypeScript requirements, emphasizing why it's strongly recommended due to decorator support for dependency injection, type safety preventing runtime errors, and improved IDE experience. Include practical examples and configuration requirements such as enabling 'experimentalDecorators' in tsconfig.json.

wiki_catalogs.name: Custom Component Development
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for custom component development in the H5 Builder Framework. Explain the process of creating new component models by extending BaseComponentModel or BaseContainerModel, including proper lifecycle implementation (onInit, onActive, onDestroy). Document how to define component props with TypeScript interfaces and inject dependencies using the @Inject decorator. Provide step-by-step guidance on creating associated View components using React and the observer pattern from mobx-vue-lite. Include best practices for state management, error handling, and resource cleanup using the Disposable pattern. Illustrate with concrete examples from the ProductCard and TabsContainer components. Address common pitfalls such as non-responsive state and memory leaks, and show how to register components with the ComponentLoader and ModelRenderer for use in schemas.

wiki_catalogs.name: Kernel Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Kernel Layer of the H5 Builder Framework. Describe its role as the foundation of the system, providing core abstractions for dependency injection, model management, and resource disposal. Explain how the DI system (InstantiationService) enables service registration, resolution, and lifecycle management with support for child injectors and error handling. Document the BaseComponentModel and BaseContainerModel classes that implement the Model-View separation pattern with reactive state management via mobx-vue-lite. Detail the DisposableStore mechanism for automated resource cleanup and memory leak prevention. Include examples from the codebase showing how components use @Inject decorators for dependency resolution, how models manage state and lifecycle hooks, and how disposable resources are registered and cleaned up automatically.

wiki_catalogs.name: Lifecycle Phases and Job Execution
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the PageLifecycle enum and its integration with the job scheduling system. Explain each lifecycle phase (Open, LoadComponentLogic, Prepare, RenderReady, Render, Completed, Idle) and their respective responsibilities in the data flow. Document how jobs like GetSchemaJob, BuildTreeJob, and InitFirstScreenDataJob are registered to specific lifecycle phases using JobScheduler. Illustrate the execution sequence with real code examples from demo-progressive.tsx, showing how prepare() and wait() methods control phase progression. Include error handling strategies for failed jobs and describe the barrier synchronization mechanism used to coordinate asynchronous operations across phases.

wiki_catalogs.name: Job Lifecycle Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the job-based execution lifecycle in the H5 Builder Framework. Detail the sequential lifecycle phases: Open (schema acquisition), LoadComponentLogic (loading model/view resources), Prepare (building model tree), RenderReady (ensuring view readiness), Render (activation and exposure tracking), Completed (initial data fetching), and Idle (post-processing). Explain how these phases coordinate across jobs via Barrier synchronization mechanisms. Document the role of PageLifecycle enum in controlling execution flow and enabling progressive rendering. Include examples from the actual implementation showing phase transitions and inter-job dependencies. Provide guidance on how to extend or customize lifecycle behavior for performance optimization or business-specific requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bridge Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the BridgeService in the H5 Builder Framework. Document the BridgeService class implementation that enables communication between JavaScript and native mobile applications via JSBridge. Explain the NativeBridge interface, BridgeCallParams, and BridgeResponse types. Detail the call method with timeout handling, error management, and response validation. Describe the mock mode functionality for browser debugging, including setMockResponse and setupMockResponses methods. Cover the BridgeHelpers utility class that provides high-level wrappers for common native operations like getUserInfo, toast, navigate, and share. Include practical usage examples for both production and development environments, integration patterns with native apps, and troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as bridge initialization failures and method invocation errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Injector
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Injector class in the H5 Builder Framework. Explain its role as the core dependency injection container that manages service registration, resolution, and lifecycle. Detail the constructor parameters including parent injector for hierarchical dependency resolution and name for debugging purposes. Document all key methods: registerInstance for registering service instances, get for retrieving services with proper error handling for missing dependencies, resolveAndInstantiate for creating instances with automatic dependency injection, createChild for creating child injectors with isolated service scopes, and dispose for cleaning up the injector and its children. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how services like HttpService are registered and retrieved. Explain the hierarchical nature of injectors and their role in scoping services (global, page-level, component-level). Address common issues such as cyclic dependencies, service not found errors, and memory leaks from improper disposal. Discuss performance considerations around service instantiation and the trade-offs between eager and lazy service creation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Job Scheduler
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the JobScheduler class in the H5 Builder Framework. Detail its role in task orchestration and phase-based execution. Explain the internal architecture including job registration via registerJob method, phase-driven instantiation, and execution control through prepare, wait, and advanceToPhase methods. Document the use of AbstractJob and JobDescriptor for defining and managing jobs, and describe how the CostRecorder tracks performance metrics. Include practical examples of registering jobs for different lifecycle phases (e.g., Start, Prepare, Render), handling asynchronous waits, and monitoring execution costs. Address integration with the DI system via IInstantiationService, error handling when duplicate jobs are added, and performance implications of phase transitions. Provide guidance on best practices for task prioritization and avoiding blocking operations in critical phases.

wiki_catalogs.name: ModelRenderer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the ModelRenderer component in the H5 Builder Framework. Explain its role as the central recursive rendering engine that maps model instances to their corresponding view components using a registration-based mapping system. Detail the implementation of the modelViewMap, the registerModelView and registerModelViews functions, and how the renderer handles different model types including BaseContainerModel, placeholder models, and unregistered components. Document the fallback rendering behavior for container components and unknown types, and explain the integration with mobx-vue-lite's observer for reactivity. Include practical examples of registering custom model-view pairs and rendering complex component trees. Address common issues such as missing view registrations, incorrect model-view mappings, and performance considerations when rendering deeply nested trees.

wiki_catalogs.name: HTTP Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the HttpService in the H5 Builder Framework. Explain its role in handling API communication with external backend systems using HTTP/HTTPS protocols. Document the implementation details including request/response interception, error handling, timeout management, and retry mechanisms. Include examples from the codebase showing how components use @Inject(HttpService) to perform GET, POST, and other HTTP operations. Describe integration with the DI system, configuration options via service identifiers, and how it handles authentication headers and CORS. Address performance considerations such as caching strategies, request batching, and payload compression. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like network errors, timeout failures, and malformed responses.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dependency Injection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Dependency Injection system in the Kernel Layer. Describe the InstantiationService as the core container that manages service registration, resolution, and lifecycle. Explain how the service registry works with ServiceCollection and ServiceIdentifier to map tokens to implementations. Document the process of dependency resolution through @Inject decorators and how the system handles circular dependencies with active instantiation tracking. Include examples from the codebase showing service registration patterns, child injector creation, and error handling mechanisms. Detail the proxy builder implementation that enables lazy service instantiation and the tracing capabilities for debugging dependency graphs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Job Scheduler
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Job Scheduler in the Flow Layer of the H5 Builder Framework. Describe its role in orchestrating the execution of asynchronous jobs across different lifecycle phases (Open, Prepare, Render, Idle) using a priority-based scheduling system. Document the internal mechanics of job registration via registerJob and addJob, phase-based instantiation, and execution control through prepare, wait, and advanceToPhase methods. Explain how the CostRecorder tracks performance metrics for each job and phase. Include examples from the codebase showing how jobs like BuildTreeJob and ActivateTreeJob are registered and executed in sequence, how dependencies between jobs are managed, and how the scheduler ensures proper ordering of operations during page initialization. Address common issues such as job duplication, phase mismatches, and performance bottlenecks, with troubleshooting guidance and optimization strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Model-View Separation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Model-View separation pattern in the H5 Builder Framework. Explain how business logic is encapsulated within models (extending BaseComponentModel) while views are pure UI components using the observer HOC from mobx-vue-lite. Document the strict separation principles: models handle data loading, state management, lifecycle hooks, and service interactions, while views only render UI and forward user events to model methods. Include concrete examples from ProductCardModel using HttpService to fetch product data and TabsContainerView rendering tabbed interfaces based on model state. Describe how changes in model properties automatically trigger view re-renders through reactivity. Address common anti-patterns to avoid, such as placing business logic in views or direct service calls from view components. Provide guidance on structuring new components following this pattern and troubleshooting issues like unresponsive UI updates or memory leaks due to improper resource management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the getting started section focused on the H5 Builder Framework. Provide step-by-step installation instructions using pnpm as shown in the README. Document the complete quick start workflow: defining a component schema, creating a model with dependency injection, creating a view with mobx-vue-lite observer, initializing the application with Injector and ComponentLoader, and rendering with ModelRenderer. Include practical code examples from the README for each step, explaining the purpose of each code block. Detail the development environment setup including TypeScript configuration requirements for decorators. Explain how to run the demo application and execute tests. Address common initial setup issues and provide troubleshooting tips for beginners.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Flow and Component Lifecycle
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the end-to-end data flow in the H5 Builder Framework. Detail the journey from Schema Definition through ComponentLoader building the Model Tree to ModelRenderer rendering the View Tree. Explain the recursive nature of model construction and view rendering, including how container models manage child models. Document the full component lifecycle from init/onInit to dispose/onDestroy, including activation/deactivation semantics. Illustrate with concrete examples how data propagates through the system and how state changes trigger re-renders via mobx-vue-lite's reactivity system. Address error handling during data flow and provide troubleshooting guidance for common data flow issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Registration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for service registration mechanisms within the Dependency Injection system. Explain how services are registered using SyncDescriptor to encapsulate constructors, static arguments, and lazy instantiation flags. Document the ServiceCollection class as the underlying registry that maps ServiceIdentifier to instances or descriptors. Cover registration patterns including immediate instantiation (instance registration), deferred instantiation (descriptor registration), and child injector isolation. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how services like HttpService or TrackerService are registered with the injector. Detail how service ownership (owned vs referenced) affects disposal behavior and memory management. Address common pitfalls such as overwriting existing registrations, incorrect descriptor configuration, and improper disposal handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dependency Injection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Dependency Injection system focused on the Injector class, @Inject decorator, and service resolution mechanism. Explain how services like HttpService and TrackerService are registered via registerInstance and resolved using resolveAndInstantiate with constructor injection. Detail the role of the @Inject decorator in marking injectable parameters and how the DI container handles circular dependencies and service ownership. Include practical examples from the README showing Injector creation, service registration, and model instantiation. Document advanced patterns like child injectors for hierarchical dependency resolution and their use cases (e.g., page-level vs global services). Address common issues such as 'service not found' errors, improper decorator setup in tsconfig, and memory leaks from un-disposed injectors. Provide troubleshooting guidance and performance tips around service lifecycle management.

wiki_catalogs.name: BaseContainerModel
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BaseContainerModel class. Explain its inheritance from BaseComponentModel and its role in managing child component models within container components like Tabs, Lists, and Grids. Document the children array property and the addChild, removeChild, and clearChildren methods for managing the collection of child models. Detail the overridden lifecycle methods: onInit (which initializes all children in parallel using Promise.all), onActive (which activates all children), and onInactive (which deactivates all children), including their console logging for debugging. Explain the override of onDestroy to ensure proper cleanup of child models through the inherited DisposableStore mechanism. Describe the automatic registration of child models via register when added, ensuring their disposal is handled automatically. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how container models coordinate the lifecycle of their children. Address common patterns such as lazy initialization of children in derived classes and performance implications of parallel initialization versus sequential loading.

wiki_catalogs.name: Schema Definition
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Schema Definition focused on the ComponentSchema interface. Document each field including type, id, props, children, and meta with their types and purposes. Explain how the schema drives dynamic component creation and tree construction. Provide concrete examples of schemas for container components like grid-layout-container and leaf components like product-card. Detail validation rules enforced by validateSchema() and error handling for missing type or id fields. Include guidance on using metadata for loading priorities and dependencies.

wiki_catalogs.name: BridgeService
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BridgeService infrastructure component. Thoroughly explain its role in enabling communication between web and native app layers in hybrid H5 applications. Document the call method's parameters, response handling, and error propagation mechanisms. Explain the mock response capabilities used for development and testing workflows. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing invocation patterns from component models. Detail integration points with HttpService for native API calls and data exchange. Address common issues such as platform compatibility, message serialization, and timeout handling. Provide guidance on debugging bridge communications and handling unsupported native features. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Idle-time Processing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Idle-time Processing focused on how the framework utilizes the Scheduler and IdleCallbackExecutor to perform non-essential work during browser idle periods. Explain the implementation of requestIdleCallback with fallback mechanisms for browsers that don't support it. Document how the scheduler prioritizes tasks using different priority levels (Start, UserInit, Prepare, Render, Idle) and how idle tasks are queued and executed only when the main thread is free. Include code examples from scheduler.ts showing the workLoop implementation and how shouldYieldToHost determines when to yield control back to the browser. Provide guidance on what types of operations are suitable for idle processing and performance benefits achieved.

wiki_catalogs.name: Infrastructure Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Infrastructure Layer of the H5 Builder Framework. This layer includes essential services: BridgeService for native app communication, HttpService for network requests, TrackerService for analytics, and PageContextService for application context management. For each service, document all methods, properties, parameters, return types, and configuration options with practical usage examples. Explain the integration patterns with external systems, error handling strategies, and security considerations. Include details on service initialization, configuration options, and testing approaches. Address common issues such as network timeouts, bridge communication failures, and tracking data consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Model-View Separation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content explaining the Model-View separation pattern in the H5 Builder framework. Describe how View components communicate with Models by calling Model methods, while Models update their reactive state to trigger automatic View re-renders through the observer pattern. Provide concrete code examples demonstrating correct implementation, including a Model class with observable properties and methods that modify state. Emphasize architectural constraints: Models must not contain DOM operations or JSX, and Views must not directly call infrastructure services like HttpService. Show examples of proper separation where DOM manipulation is handled through state changes in the View, and business logic with service calls is encapsulated within Models. Reference the BaseComponentModel and ModelRenderer implementations to illustrate the framework's enforcement of this pattern.

wiki_catalogs.name: Framework Extension Points
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for framework extension points in the H5 Builder. Document how to extend the Dependency Injection system by creating custom service registries and child injectors. Explain the process of adding new infrastructure services (like custom analytics or native bridge implementations) by registering them with the Injector and defining appropriate service identifiers. Cover how to create and register new job types in the scheduler system for custom initialization or rendering logic, using existing jobs like GetSchemaJob and BuildTreeJob as reference. Include examples of extending the ComponentService to support new component types and modifying the job execution flow. Address integration patterns with external systems and provide guidance on maintaining type safety when extending core interfaces.

wiki_catalogs.name: Infrastructure Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Infrastructure Layer of the H5 Builder Framework. Describe its role in providing cross-cutting services that enable communication with external systems and runtime environment. Document the HttpService for API communication with request/response handling, the BridgeService for native app integration, the TrackerService for analytics and monitoring, and the ContextService for global application state management. Explain how these services are registered with the DI container and consumed by components through dependency injection. Include examples from the codebase showing how components use @Inject(HttpService) to make API calls, how tracker service handles event reporting, and how bridge service facilitates web-native communication. Address error handling, security considerations, and performance implications of these infrastructure services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Model Tree Construction Process
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the model tree construction process. Explain how BuildTreeJob uses ComponentService to transform a ComponentSchema into a hierarchical tree of BaseComponentModel instances. Document the recursive nature of model creation, including how BaseContainerModel manages child models through addChild() and initializes them via onInit(). Use the TestContainerModel example from model.test.ts to illustrate parent-child model relationships. Detail the role of DI in injecting required services during model instantiation and explain how props are passed from schema to model constructors. Address common issues such as schema validation errors and circular dependencies, and provide performance optimization tips for large model trees.

wiki_catalogs.name: Get Schema Job
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the GetSchemaJob component. Thoroughly explain its implementation details, including how it initiates during the Open phase, fetches schema via SchemaService, and registers component loaders with priority-based preloading. Document the use of Barrier for phase synchronization and the integration with ComponentService for async component registration. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing registration patterns for ProductCard, TextCard, TabsContainer, and other components with their respective priority and delay configurations. Explain relationships with other components like SchemaService and how error handling is managed during schema acquisition. Address common issues such as schema fetch failures and race conditions, and provide solutions.

wiki_catalogs.name: HTTP Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the HttpService in the H5 Builder Framework. Explain how it leverages JSBridge for network requests while providing a familiar axios-like interface. Document the HttpRequestConfig and HttpResponse interfaces, request method overloads (get, post, put, delete), and timeout handling. Detail the interceptor system including request, response, and error interceptors with examples of how to add and remove them. Explain the configuration options such as baseURL and token that enable automatic request transformation. Describe the pending request tracking system using AbortController and the cancelAll method for cleanup. Cover the dispose lifecycle method and resource management. Provide practical examples demonstrating common usage patterns, interceptor implementation for authentication and logging, and error handling strategies. Address performance considerations and best practices for managing concurrent requests.

wiki_catalogs.name: DisposableStore
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the DisposableStore class, which serves as the foundation for automated resource management in the H5 Builder Framework. Explain its implementation as an LIFO (Last-In-First-Out) resource cleanup system that prevents memory leaks by ensuring proper disposal of event listeners, timers, subscriptions, and other resources. Document the add method for registering disposables or cleanup functions, emphasizing the protection against self-registration and the warning mechanism when adding to already disposed stores. Detail the dispose method's behavior, including its idempotency check, LIFO disposal order, and error aggregation strategy that collects all disposal errors before throwing an AggregateError. Explain the clear method's role in the disposal process and the internal Set implementation that tracks disposables. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how DisposableStore is used within BaseComponentModel to manage component resources. Address common issues such as attempting to add disposables to disposed stores, handling errors during disposal, and the importance of proper disposal chaining in component hierarchies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Loader
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the ComponentService (ComponentLoader) responsible for transforming component schemas into executable model trees. Explain the full lifecycle from schema validation to model instantiation using the DI container. Detail key methods such as register, registerAll, and buildTree, including how they interact with the ComponentRegistry and BaseComponentModel hierarchy. Describe the recursive model tree construction process, child model integration in BaseContainerModel, and error recovery via ErrorPlaceholderModel. Document the asynchronous loading capabilities through registerAsync and preloadComponentsUnified, including concurrency control mechanisms and caching strategies. Illustrate the separation between model loading (with dependency injection) and view loading (with model-view mapping registration). Provide concrete usage examples showing schema-to-model transformation, error handling during component creation, and integration with tracking services. Address performance considerations around schema validation overhead, memory usage in large trees, and optimization techniques like lazy loading and preloading strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: VirtualList
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the VirtualList component, a performance-optimized list rendering solution supporting both fixed and dynamic height modes. Explain the architecture of VirtualListModel and VirtualListView, including the height caching mechanism, scroll position tracking, and visible item calculation. Document the props interface including containerHeight, itemHeight, estimatedItemHeight, and overscan. Describe the dynamic height measurement system where VirtualListItem components measure their own height using requestAnimationFrame and report back to the model. Detail the rendering mechanics including paddingTop, paddingBottom for scroll buffer, and the use of absolute positioning. Provide usage examples with different data types and renderItem patterns. Address common implementation challenges such as handling variable content, optimizing measurement performance, and integrating with the model-view system. Include performance optimization tips and troubleshooting guidance for common issues like incorrect scrolling behavior or height miscalculations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bridge Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BridgeService, which enables communication between the H5 web application and native mobile app environments. Explain its implementation using message passing patterns, event emitters, and platform detection logic. Document how it exposes native functionalities (e.g., camera, geolocation, payment) to web components through a unified interface. Include code examples showing how components invoke native features via @Inject(BridgeService) and handle asynchronous responses. Describe the message serialization format, error propagation from native layer, and security considerations for preventing unauthorized access. Address debugging techniques for bridge communication issues and compatibility across different mobile platforms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Model System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Model System component. Thoroughly explain the BaseComponentModel and BaseContainerModel classes that implement the Model-View separation pattern. Document the lifecycle methods (init/onInit, activate/onActive, etc.) and how they coordinate with the rendering system. Include concrete examples from the component_development_guide showing model creation with dependency injection and state management. Explain the relationship between models and views through the ModelRenderer component. Address common issues like proper state initialization and lifecycle hook ordering. Provide guidance on extending base models for custom components and best practices for reactive state management using mobx-vue-lite.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Loader
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Component Loader subsystem within the Flow Layer. Thoroughly explain its implementation details, including the buildTree method that recursively constructs the model tree from component schemas, the validation of schema integrity, and error handling for unknown component types or missing fields. Document the internal registry mechanism that maps component types to model classes, and the lazy loading capabilities via preloadComponentsUnified that asynchronously load model and view modules. Explain the integration with the Dependency Injection system through instantiationService and tracking via TrackerService. Include concrete examples from the codebase demonstrating how a schema is transformed into a fully initialized model tree, how child components are built and attached to container models, and how errors are gracefully handled by inserting placeholder components. Address common issues such as circular dependencies, schema validation failures, and race conditions during parallel loading, providing solutions and best practices for reliable component loading.

wiki_catalogs.name: ModelRenderer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the ModelRenderer component in the H5 Builder Framework. Describe its role as the central engine that traverses the model tree and renders corresponding views based on registered Model-View mappings. Explain how it uses a Map to store model-class-to-view-component associations and resolves the correct view at runtime. Document its handling of special cases like placeholder components (Error, Loading, Empty) and container models that may not have explicitly registered views. Include analysis of the recursive rendering mechanism for container children and fallback rendering strategies. Use code examples from model-renderer.tsx to illustrate lookup logic, conditional rendering paths, and error handling. Address performance considerations, such as minimizing re-renders through proper observer usage, and integration points with the component registration system. wiki_catalogs.name: Core Concepts

wiki_catalogs.name: Debugging
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed debugging documentation for the H5 Builder framework. Explain how to enable debug modes for key services: BridgeService debug mode for mock functionality and TrackerService debug mode for synchronous event sending with toast notifications. Provide code examples showing instantiation of these services with debug flags. Describe techniques for inspecting the Model tree structure through browser developer tools by logging root models and their children hierarchies. Explain lifecycle tracing by adding console.log statements in lifecycle methods (onInit, onActive, etc.) to track component state changes. Include practical debugging workflows and tips for diagnosing common issues, referencing the actual service implementations to ensure accuracy in the debugging guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Infrastructure Services
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Infrastructure Services including HttpService, BridgeService, TrackerService, and ContextService. For each service, document its purpose, public API methods, configuration options, and usage patterns. Explain how HttpService handles requests with interceptors and integrates with BridgeService for native calls. Document BridgeService's call method and mock response capabilities. Detail TrackerService's track, flush, and clear methods along with its batching and persistence configuration. Explain ContextService's role in managing user, environment, and route information. Include practical examples from the API reference showing service integration in component models.

wiki_catalogs.name: Common Errors
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive troubleshooting content for common errors encountered when using the H5 Builder framework. Address state not updating issues by explaining three key solutions: ensuring properties are declared as public class fields for reactivity, verifying Views are wrapped with the observer HOC, and avoiding direct modification of nested objects (requiring full object replacement). Resolve the 'Cannot find name window' TypeScript error by recommending adding 'DOM' to the lib array in tsconfig.json. Fix components not rendering by checking three prerequisites: component registration with ComponentLoader, Model-View mapping registration with ModelRenderer, and correct schema type matching. Provide complete code examples showing both incorrect and correct implementations for each scenario, and reference the relevant source files to ensure solutions are technically accurate and up-to-date.

wiki_catalogs.name: Performance Optimization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Performance Optimization focused on Lazy Loading, Idle-time Processing, and Virtual Scrolling. Explain how the scheduler system uses JobScheduler with different priorities (Start, UserInit, Prepare, Render, Idle) to optimize task execution. Document the idle-time processing capabilities using scheduleIdleTask for non-critical work. Detail the auto-virtual-scroll feature that automatically enables virtual scrolling for container components with many children, including the threshold detection logic and configuration options. Include performance comparisons from the auto-virtual-scroll documentation showing the significant improvements in rendering time and memory usage. Provide best practices for implementing lazy loading in container components and optimizing long lists.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for all public interfaces in the H5 Builder Framework. Organize by architectural layer: Kernel Layer (Injector, DisposableStore, BaseComponentModel, BaseContainerModel), Infrastructure Layer (BridgeService, HttpService, TrackerService, PageContextService), Flow Layer (JobScheduler, ComponentLoader), and Components (ModelRenderer, VirtualList). For each API, document all methods, properties, parameters, return types, and exceptions. Include code examples from the API reference document showing proper usage patterns. Document configuration interfaces and their default values. Address versioning considerations and backward compatibility. Provide migration guidance for any deprecated APIs. Ensure complete coverage of all public methods and interfaces exposed by the framework.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Development Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for component development following the principles in the component_development_guide.md. Explain the step-by-step process of creating a new component: defining the model class that extends BaseComponentModel, implementing lifecycle methods, injecting services via @Inject, and managing state with reactivity. Detail the creation of the view component using React and mobx-vue-lite's observer HOC. Document the registration process with ComponentLoader and ModelRenderer. Include common patterns such as data loading, error handling, computed properties, timer management, and event subscription. Provide best practices for state management, error handling, and resource cleanup. Address common pitfalls and their solutions as documented in the guide.

wiki_catalogs.name: Testing Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the testing strategy focused on unit and integration testing of components and services. Explain how to test models using Vitest, including setting up the Injector with mock services, creating test instances with resolveAndInstantiate, and verifying state changes and method calls. Document testing patterns for lifecycle methods, service interactions, and error handling. Include examples from the test files showing how to mock HttpService, TrackerService, and other dependencies. Explain how to test complex scenarios like asynchronous operations and error conditions. Address testing of the DI system, resource management, and lifecycle hooks. Provide guidance on achieving high test coverage and maintaining test reliability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frequently Asked Questions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive FAQ content addressing common questions and issues from the faq.md document. Organize by category:入门问题 (Getting Started), Model-View 分离, 依赖注入 (Dependency Injection), 生命周期 (Lifecycle), 性能优化 (Performance Optimization), 测试 (Testing), 调试 (Debugging), and 常见错误 (Common Errors). For each question, provide a clear, concise answer with practical examples and code snippets where appropriate. Include troubleshooting guidance for issues like state not updating, memory leaks, dependency injection failures, and component rendering problems. Document debugging techniques such as enabling debug modes, tracing lifecycle methods, and inspecting the model tree. Ensure all questions from the original FAQ are addressed with accurate, up-to-date information.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced Topics
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed content for advanced topics in the H5 Builder Framework. Cover custom component development beyond basic patterns, including complex container components with dynamic child management and advanced state synchronization. Document framework extension points such as adding custom services, extending the DI system, and creating new job types in the scheduler. Explain performance tuning techniques for large-scale applications, including memory optimization, startup time reduction, and rendering performance improvements. Detail integration with external systems beyond the built-in services, such as custom analytics providers or native app features. Address advanced debugging and monitoring strategies for production applications. Include expert-level usage patterns from the component development guide and README.

wiki_items.title: Component Lifecycle Hooks and State Management

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: H5 Builder Framework

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
The H5 Builder Framework is a specialized e-commerce H5 page building system that implements a robust architecture for dynamic page construction using schema-driven components. The framework enables the creation of complex, interactive H5 pages through a structured Model-View separation pattern.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Implement a complete dependency injection system for service management
- Establish strict separation between business logic (Model) and UI rendering (View)
- Provide automated resource management to prevent memory leaks
- Support tree-based component architecture for hierarchical page structures
- Enable lazy loading and performance optimization for large-scale applications

### Target Audience
This framework is designed for frontend developers building e-commerce H5 applications, particularly those requiring:
- Dynamic page generation from schemas
- Complex component hierarchies
- High-performance long lists and virtual scrolling
- Strict separation of concerns between business logic and UI
- Comprehensive lifecycle management

Sources:
- [README.md](packages/h5-builder/README.md)

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The project follows a monorepo structure with two main packages:
- **@mobx-monorepo/h5-builder**: The core H5 builder framework with DI, reactive state, and component management
- **mobx-vue-lite**: A lightweight MobX implementation using Vue's reactivity system

The architecture is organized into distinct layers:
- **Kernel Layer**: DI container, Model base classes, and resource management
- **Infrastructure Layer**: Http, Bridge, Tracker, and Context services
- **Flow Layer**: Job scheduling and component loading
- **Business Components**: Domain-specific components like ProductCard and TabsContainer
- **View Layer**: React components for UI rendering

### Design Patterns
The framework implements several key design patterns:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Schema Definition] --> B[ComponentLoader]
    B --> C[DI Container]
    C --> D[Service Instantiation]
    D --> E[Model Tree]
    E --> F[ModelRenderer]
    F --> G[View Tree]
    G --> H[React Rendering]
```

### System Relationships
The system follows a unidirectional data flow from schema definition to final rendering:

```mermaid
graph TD
    Schema[Component Schema] --> Loader[ComponentService]
    Loader --> DI[Dependency Injection]
    DI --> Model[Model Tree]
    Model --> Renderer[ModelRenderer]
    Renderer --> View[React Components]
    View --> DOM[Browser DOM]
    
    Tracker[TrackerService] --> Analytics[Analytics System]
    Http[HttpService] --> API[Backend APIs]
    Bridge[BridgeService] --> Native[Native App]
```

### Data Flow
The data flow follows a clear pattern from initialization to rendering:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Define Schema] --> B[Initialize Injector]
    B --> C[Register Services]
    C --> D[Create ComponentLoader]
    D --> E[Build Model Tree]
    E --> F[Initialize Models]
    F --> G[Render with ModelRenderer]
    G --> H[User Interaction]
    H --> I[Model State Update]
    I --> J[Automatic View Re-render]
```

Sources:
- [package.json](packages/h5-builder/package.json)
- [README.md](packages/h5-builder/README.md)
- [instantiation-service.ts](packages/h5-builder/src/bedrock/di/instantiation-service.ts)
- [model.ts](packages/h5-builder/src/bedrock/model.ts)

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- **packages/h5-builder/src/components/model-renderer.tsx**: The central component that renders models as views
- **packages/h5-builder/src/services/component.service.ts**: The core service for building component trees from schemas
- **packages/h5-builder/src/bedrock/di/instantiation-service.ts**: The dependency injection system implementation

### Core Modules
- **Dependency Injection System**: A comprehensive DI container with support for service registration, instantiation, and lifecycle management
- **Model-View Separation**: Base classes for models that separate business logic from UI concerns
- **Component Registry**: A system for registering and resolving component types to their implementations
- **Resource Management**: Automated disposal system to prevent memory leaks

### Configuration Approach
The framework uses a combination of runtime configuration and code-based setup:

```mermaid
graph LR
    Config[Configuration] -->|package.json| Build[Build Configuration]
    Config -->|tsconfig.json| Types[TypeScript Configuration]
    Config -->|vite.config.ts| Dev[Development Server]
    Config -->|Component Metadata| Runtime[Runtime Behavior]
```

Sources:
- [model-renderer.tsx](packages/h5-builder/src/components/model-renderer.tsx)
- [component.service.ts](packages/h5-builder/src/services/component.service.ts)
- [instantiation-service.ts](packages/h5-builder/src/bedrock/di/instantiation-service.ts)
- [model.ts](packages/h5-builder/src/bedrock/model.ts)

### External Dependencies
- **mobx-vue-lite**: Lightweight state management using Vue's reactivity system
- **@vue/reactivity**: Vue 3's reactivity system for observable state
- **React 19**: UI rendering library
- **Vite**: Development server and build tool
- **Vitest**: Testing framework

### Integration Points
- **BridgeService**: Integration with native app functionality
- **HttpService**: Integration with backend APIs
- **TrackerService**: Integration with analytics systems
- **PageContextService**: Integration with global application context

### Component Relationships
The framework establishes clear relationships between components:

```mermaid
graph LR
    Injector[Injector] -->|Provides| ComponentService
    ComponentService -->|Builds| ModelTree
    ModelTree -->|Contains| Models
    Models -->|Depends on| Services
    ModelRenderer -->|Renders| Models
    ModelRenderer -->|Uses| ViewComponents
    ViewComponents -->|Display| ModelData
```

Sources:
- [package.json](packages/h5-builder/package.json)
- [component.service.ts](packages/h5-builder/src/services/component.service.ts)
- [model-renderer.tsx](packages/h5-builder/src/components/model-renderer.tsx)
- [instantiation-service.ts](packages/h5-builder/src/bedrock/di/instantiation-service.ts)

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The H5 Builder Framework provides a comprehensive set of features for building dynamic H5 pages:

- **Schema-Driven Components**: Define page structure through JSON-like schemas
- **Dependency Injection**: Automatic injection of services into components
- **Reactive State Management**: Automatic view updates when model state changes
- **Complete Lifecycle Management**: Init, activate, deactivate, and dispose hooks
- **Error Isolation**: Component errors don't affect the entire application
- **Lazy Loading**: Support for code splitting and on-demand loading
- **Performance Optimization**: Idle-time processing and virtual scrolling

### Implementation Highlights
- **Model-View Separation**: Clear separation between business logic and UI rendering
- **Tree-Based Architecture**: Hierarchical component structure from schema to view
- **Automated Resource Cleanup**: Disposable pattern to prevent memory leaks
- **Comprehensive Testing**: 100% test coverage with 96+ test cases

### Feature Architecture
The framework's feature architecture follows a layered approach:

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Initialization
    Initialization --> SchemaParsing: Parse schema
    SchemaParsing --> DIConfiguration: Configure DI
    DIConfiguration --> ModelTreeConstruction: Build model tree
    ModelTreeConstruction --> ModelInitialization: Initialize models
    ModelInitialization --> ViewRendering: Render views
    ViewRendering --> UserInteraction: Wait for interaction
    UserInteraction --> StateUpdate: Update model state
    StateUpdate --> ViewReRendering: Re-render views
    ViewReRendering --> UserInteraction
```

Sources:
- [README.md](packages/h5-builder/README.md)
- [component_development_guide.md](packages/h5-builder/docs/component_development_guide.md)
- [api_reference.md](packages/h5-builder/docs/api_reference.md)
- [faq.md](packages/h5-builder/docs/faq.md)
</blog>
